Over the past month Shopify has announced the depreciation of a couple of core apps and features. The two notable ones are the [Product Reviews app](https://help.shopify.com/en/manual/products/product-reviews?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-46-shopify-s-deprecated-apps) and the [Geolocation app](https://help.shopify.com/en/manual/markets/international-domains/directing-customers/geolocation?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-46-shopify-s-deprecated-apps), which will be deprecated on May 6th and December 1st, respectively.

Shopify has notoriously launched apps and then not allocated any dev resources to updating them. Some examples are the [Planet app](https://apps.shopify.com/planet?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-46-shopify-s-deprecated-apps), [Digital Downloads app](https://apps.shopify.com/digital-downloads?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-46-shopify-s-deprecated-apps) and [Fraud Filter app](https://apps.shopify.com/fraud-filter?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-46-shopify-s-deprecated-apps).

Both aforementioned apps have been removed from the app store, but from my memory they also didn‚Äôt have many updates after the initial release. However, from my experience both apps worked well, albeit sometimes a bit finicky.
What does this signal about Shopify?

I understand why they are deprecating the Geolocation app. Over the years Shopify has made advancements in their localization redirection technologies that make the Geolocation app redundant. These include expansion in their automation redirection feature, automation browser language redirection andconsolidation of the GeoIP feature. Now Shopify Markets should be enough for most merchants to manage redirections to various markets.

On the other hand, deprecating the Product Reviews app seems like a forced cash grab. It is compatible with Online Store 2.0 themes and the functionality is generally fine. I know Shopify tries to give as much opportunity to app developers as possible, but in this case I believe product reviews are a core feature to any ecommerce platform. Shopify‚Äôs model so far has been to offer the most basic features as free and let the 3rd party apps take care of any fancy features. They‚Äôve done this for Subscriptions, Translations, Search & Filter and more.

Shopify seems to be wanting to go up-market so maybe this is part of their strategy. All I hope is that by letting these apps go, they will be able to gather more dev resources for bigger and better features that will positively impact everyone.
- IBM Equal Access Accessibility Checker: A google extension that is recommended by theWorld Wide Web Consortium (W3C)‚Äôs Web Accessibility Initiative, the official body on web accessibility.

- Devin, the first AI software engineer: The software world has been going crazy over Cognition Labs new release, which claims to be ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs first fully autonomous AI software engineer‚Äù. What are your thoughts on it?
- Baymard Institute: A great resource for keeping up to date with the latest UX trends in ecommerce with comprehensive UX research.

This app is great for B2B clients that have varying prices for different customer tiers. I‚Äôve used this for all of my B2B clients and it's been extremely straightforward. The team takes care of setting up the required coding snippets within your theme. One feature I love is that you can have custom prices per variant which is super helpful for honing in on your specific pricing.

Hone in on your freelancing skill sets rather than branch out to many other skills. A¬† lot of freelancers at the start of their journey think it‚Äôs better to offer as many skills as possible because broader skills === more clients, right? Actually, more often than not it‚Äôs the opposite. Clients are confused about what you do. When clients look to hire they are looking for the best person that can solve their specific problem. If you‚Äôre just one person you will not convince clients that you are an expert in branding marketing, coding and PR. It‚Äôs better to hone in on one skills, such as coding and be THE coding person.

The funny thing is, the longer I‚Äôve been freelancing, the more I‚Äôve found that I can learn within my skill. Clients will come to you because you can code good websites. But within a high quality website there‚Äôs accessibility, site speed, SEO, general code quality, and more. It can be even more powerful to be THE site speed person or THE accessibility person.

When I first started freelancing I did everything under the sun in order to explore my possibilities. I built MVPs for startups, contracted for software agencies, built one-page personal sites, worked on WooCommerce and Shopify sites, and even got a lucrative contract working for a government contractor (that‚Äôs a story for another day).

I found my passion in ecommerce and decided to go for Shopify. Of course it was scary to technically be offering less. But as mentioned before, as you dive deeper into a topic you find there‚Äôs so much more to enhance. It‚Äôs easier to market yourself, easier to have your mind in one place and ultimately, I‚Äôm as busy as ever. So it worked out in the end üòÄ
I hope you enjoyed this edition. If you have any feedback, or better ways to do the things I touched on, let me know your thoughts!

"i only speak liquid" #45: UPDATED! Product Recommendations Tracking Parameters,Written by Jocelyn (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-45-updated-product-recommendations-tracking-parameters,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Hey everyone!Tim here from Storetasker HQ - Just wanted to apologize because I mis-formatted some of Jocelyn‚Äôs code in the yesterday‚Äôs newsie + caused a weird duplication of content in the ‚Äú1 app I like section‚Äù.

So please ignore yesterday‚Äôs email and focus on this one üôÇWithout further ado: Here is [Jocelyn‚Äôs](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/jocelyn-dunkley?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-45-updated-product-recommendations-tracking-parameters) 1st edit of i_only_speak_liquid, all edited properly this time!

One of our retainer client‚Äôs SEO consultants came to me about an issue with Shopify‚Äôs product recommendation URLs in Google Search Console. I didn‚Äôt know this, but Shopify adds many [tracking IDs](https://shopify.dev/docs/api/ajax/reference/product-recommendations?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-45-updated-product-recommendations-tracking-parameters#tracking-conversions-for-product-recommendations) into the product recommendation URLs in order to create reports.

This was causing the Shopify site to experience a below par internal structure that made it unnecessarily difficult for crawlers to crawl all the pages within the website. The tracking parameters were good for internal Shopify statistics, but it also created 10 times the amount of unique URLs the crawler had to follow.
There are 2 options to fix this:

- If you don‚Äôt care about tracking recommended product performance: Strip the tracking data from the URLs likehttps://great-website.com/products/white-leather-holiday-short-blue-triminstead ofhttps://great-website.com/products/white-leather-holiday-short-blue-trim?pr_prod_strat=copurchase&pr_rec_id=3330c9992&pr_rec_pid=8835401843011&pr_ref_pid=8835398336835&pr_seq=uniform. This way we profit from the extra internal links, but lose the tracking possibilities within Shopify.
- If you want to track performance: Add ‚Äúrel=‚Äônofollow‚Äô‚Äù to the link. This solution will keep the tracking within Shopify, but the crawler will ignore those links.
The client didn‚Äôt care about tracking the recommended product performance so we went with option #1
I achieved this with the following change to the recommended products URL:
It was quite a simple solution but it was an interesting process learning about the impact of tracking on SEO.

[Using JavaScript to manage the cart](https://nozzlegear.com/shopify/using-javascript-to-manage-a-shopify-cart?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-45-updated-product-recommendations-tracking-parameters): A ‚Äúback to basics‚Äù guide about the Shopify cart and working with it. It also gives some helpful examples about using and working with the FormData interface.

[Limited Supply podcast](https://www.youtube.com/@limitedsupply?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-45-updated-product-recommendations-tracking-parameters): Interesting perspectives about DTC discussed in a cool, unfiltered way. It also helps me understand the thought process merchants and marketers have behind the scenes of projects before they reach out to developers.

[Shopify Performance blog](https://performance.shopify.com/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-45-updated-product-recommendations-tracking-parameters): Detailed blogs and guides about site speed optimization in the context of Shopify stores. Many site optimization recommendations can‚Äôt be applied to Shopify stores due to constraints like 3rd party apps so having a Shopify-specific guide from the mothership is very helpful.
- You can completely customize the subscription widget look and feel in Liquid directly in the app. No more hacky CSS like in Recharge
- Amazing customer service and free white glove migration from other subscription apps

In 2022 I had a client that was looking to migrate from Bold subscriptions to another app. I did a deep dive of 8 different apps. I got on sales calls and tested them out on my development store. I decided to recommend Loop because the customer service was fantastic and the app was robust and hit all of the client‚Äôs pain points. I even became one of their [first agency partnerships](https://loopsubscriptions.partnerpage.io/agencies?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-45-updated-product-recommendations-tracking-parameters). Go check it out if you need a new subscription app!

Context is key for a project. It‚Äôs why getting on a call is so important. Sometimes as developers we just take a task and run with it without asking any questions. But taking the time to really understand the business, the project and why it‚Äôs needed can be invaluable. It will help to have more empathy with the client and make relevant suggestions down the line.

For example, I got on a call last week with a lead that wanted to adapt their Shopify store for franchisees because they were planning on securing franchise agreements in the next 6 months. They wanted to have the same look and feel across all the franchises but the product selection and site content would be slightly different. The options were either to figure out a way to switch between these different environments on the same store or build separate stores for each franchise.

The important context here was that the franchise owners would barely touch the site at all. Also the ‚Äúfranchises‚Äù were just different production centers. Some of the centers couldn‚Äôt create some of the products which necessitated this kind of product curation.
This opened my mind to truly understand the problem and we are working now to find a solution using the same Shopify store.
Hope you enjoyed my first edition. If you have any feedback, or better ways to do the things I touched on, let me know your thoughts!

"i only speak liquid" #44: Being clear with your clients,Written by Joe (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-44-clear-clients,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Welcome back! This is my 4th and final edit of [i_only_speak_liquid](https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/) - thanks for having me in your inbox for the past couple of months! I‚Äôm [Joe](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/joe-callon?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-44-being-clear-with-your-clients), a [Storetasker](https://resources.storetasker.com/become-an-expert?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-44-being-clear-with-your-clients) expert and front-end developer who has worked within Shopify‚Äôs Plus Support team, agencies, and as a freelancer for a good few years. For the final time, let‚Äôs go!

I‚Äôve been putting some thought into how you can make your work stand out as a freelance developer in the Shopify space. Plenty of people offer similar services to you, often at a lower price, so what can you do to ensure the clients you want choose to work with you? One thing I‚Äôve found throughout my career working in agencies and with large enterprise clients, is that clear information is invaluable to them.

This can be something as large as putting together a rigorous functional specification for the client‚Äôs new store or theme, or it can be as tiny as includinginfoelements within your schema for settings to let the client know what something does when they‚Äôre playing around with their lovely new site.

This may sound silly, but something as small as this can help you stand out from a freelancer working for a small fee who is happy to cut corners and get the task out of the door. Whilst the work they produce may work in the present, their code and setup may be too confusing to change in the future, or the client just may entirely misunderstand what a setting or field is used for within their theme due to poor communication.

Just by adding some explainer text into your merchant‚Äôs theme editor, you‚Äôre keeping yourself in conversation with them long into the future as they continue to adapt your work as their business needs change, and this keeps at the front of their mind.

They may add a section to their homepage and see the incredibly handy ‚ÄúThis setting does X‚Äù or ‚ÄúEnter Y here to do Z‚Äù text in the customiser. They remember how great you were to work with, and they‚Äôre more inclined to reach out to you again in the future as they‚Äôre reminded of the great experience and the way you thought about them holistically, and not just another task on a to-do list.

[Top Front-End Tools of 2023](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2024/01/top-frontend-tools-2023/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-44-being-clear-with-your-clients) - it‚Äôs good to know what everyone else is up to, and Smashing Magazine keep on top of things with their yearly roundup of the most popular tools shared via their newsletter over 2023

[Where have all the websites gone?](https://www.fromjason.xyz/p/notebook/where-have-all-the-websites-gone/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-44-being-clear-with-your-clients) - a look at the loss of the ‚Äúwebsite‚Äù, everything is just apps now, and it‚Äôs a loss felt for this guy who grew up obsessed with websites (hence my current career and the fact you‚Äôre reading this newsletter!)

[Theme blocks](https://www.shopify.com/uk/partners/blog/themeblocks?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-44-being-clear-with-your-clients)- now available in developer preview, repeatable ‚Äútheme blocks‚Äù will likely become a big part of your workflow when they go into production, so get ahead now by taking a look over Shopify‚Äôs blog post and documentation on them to see how you can make the most out of this, in my opinion, very handy new featur

[GA: Age Verification](https://apps.shopify.com/ga-age-verification-18?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-44-being-clear-with-your-clients) - a great, customisable option for your clients who may need to lock down their site for selling alcohol or other, even more exciting things üëÄ

One thing about relying on yourself for work is that you should always expect clients to do the unexpected. They may hit you up for a project, spend time scoping with you, and then decide against it entirely, or you may find out they‚Äôve been shopping around for other quotes, thanks for your time, no hard feelings etc but you‚Äôre just that little too pricy for them right now!

This all comes with part of being a freelancer and learning not to take any knockbacks too harshly and as a personal affront to your business is hard, but it‚Äôs a key part of being successful. There‚Äôs no use in throwing more wasted time into something by worrying about it or agonising over how much thought you put into a project that didn‚Äôt work out. Take a breath, and move on to the next one.

That‚Äôs all from me on IOSL, [you can stay in touch with me via LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/joecallon?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-44-being-clear-with-your-clients), thanks a lot for having me!

"i only speak liquid" #43: Shopify Editions Winter 2024,Written by Joe (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

This is my third edit of [i_only_speak_liquid](https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/) - hopefully you‚Äôre not sick of me just yet! I‚Äôm [Joe](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/joe-callon?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024), a [Storetasker](https://resources.storetasker.com/become-an-expert?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024) expert and front-end developer who has worked within Shopify‚Äôs Plus Support team, agencies, and as a freelancer for a good few years.Let‚Äôs get going!

It‚Äôs unlikely you‚Äôve missed [Shopify‚Äôs latest raft of announcements as part of their Editions series](https://www.shopify.com/editions/winter2024?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024), but if you have, your local reporter Joe is here to fix that.

The biggest announcement came in the form of the updates to the product model Shopify uses, which will now let you list out individual colour variants as products (Plus-only, for now!) and create more rich categorisation. The main headline here though, is that the rollout has begun to allow up to 2000 variants per product - the 100 limit for this has been one of Shopify‚Äôs biggest bugbears since I started working on the platform, so this is amazing to finally see change. There‚Äôs also [support for swatches](https://help.shopify.com/en/manual/online-store/themes/theme-structure/theme-settings?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024#options-with-swatches)!

In the world of discounts, free shipping can now be offered automatically and you can take a fixed amount off Buy X Get Y discounts. Shopify is also now finally offering out their first-party Bundles and Subscriptions apps to everyone, which is huge for anyone still relying on janky apps to power essential parts of their business model.

For us developers, [there‚Äôs some really cool stuff here](https://www.shopify.com/editions/winter2024?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024#developer), including theme blocks, which let you pre-define blocks that can be used across sections so your clients don‚Äôt need to duplicate content across their store. This also means support for nesting blocks has been added, which while things might be getting a little confusing from a Liquid point of view, creates a much more robust system of managing content.
These changes are in developer preview for now, but they work well and I can‚Äôt imagine it‚Äôll be too long before they‚Äôre pushed out everywhere.
Genuinely, there‚Äôs too much stuff to list in one email, so go check out the Editions page for yourself and then come back wowed and ready to read on for some wonderful recommendations!

[You are never taught how to build quality software](https://www.florianbellmann.com/blog/never-taught-qa?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024) - interesting thoughts on how most developers aren‚Äôt inclined to consider QA in their work

[Creatica](https://creatica.app/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024) - there are plenty of background/artwork generators out there, but this one is very nicely done

[Pic Copilot](https://www.piccopilot.com/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024) - image generator built with eCommerce in mind, easily lets you put products in all manner of places without having to leave your desk

[Consentmo](https://apps.shopify.com/gdpr-backpack?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-43-shopify-editions-winter-2024) - one of the only ‚Äúboring‚Äù Shopify apps that doesn‚Äôt make me shudder when I see a client has it installed, it‚Äôs full of all the necessary features to handle cookie consent without feeling overblown

When relying on yourself for work, you should always expect clients to do the unexpected. They may hit you up for a project, spend time scoping with you, and then decide against it entirely, or you may find out they‚Äôve been shopping around for other quotes: thanks for your time, no hard feelings etc but you‚Äôre just that little too pricy for them right now!

While you‚Äôre working for someone else, it‚Äôs all too easy to forget the sales process that comes before the tasks hit your deck, but as a freelancer you‚Äôre obviously in charge of this process, and it can be hard. There is definitely something to be said for the comfort in knowing bringing the work in simply isn‚Äôt your responsibility. It can feel like a failure to be told you didn‚Äôt make the cut by a client, but if you‚Äôre doing good work, the right clients will come to you in time.

This all comes with part of being a freelancer and learning not to take any knockbacks too harshly and as a personal affront to your business is hard, but it‚Äôs a key part of being successful. There‚Äôs no use in throwing more wasted time into something by worrying about it or agonising over how much thought you put into a project that didn‚Äôt work out. Take a breath, and move on to the next one.

"i only speak liquid" #42: Making Theme Previews Easy,Written by Joe (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-42-making-theme-previews-easy,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Welcome back to my second edit of ‚Äòi_only_speak_liquid‚Äô to kick off 2024, hope your new year is going well so far! I‚Äôm [Joe](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/joe-callon?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-42-making-theme-previews-easy), a [Storetasker](https://resources.storetasker.com/become-an-expert?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-42-making-theme-previews-easy) expert and front-end developer who has worked within Shopify‚Äôs Plus Support team, agencies, and as a freelancer for a good few years. Let‚Äôs get going!

If you‚Äôre a front end developer within the Shopify space, you‚Äôre probably pretty used to sharing your work with your team or client by heading into the Shopify admin, clicking the three small dots and right-clicking the Preview link to grab the URL for the version of your client‚Äôs store with your latest changes. This works, but it feels clunky, and will only ever direct the recipient to the homepage of the store you‚Äôre working on.

Shopify‚Äôs theme preview bar is also buggy, and the .shopifypreview.com links it generates don‚Äôt send you to the exact URL they‚Äôre generated from, and don‚Äôt allow for checking out whilst browsing, which is all to say, it‚Äôs a pretty poor experience.

To get around this, I‚Äôve added a bookmarklet in my Chrome bookmarks bar which when clicked, automatically copies the URL of the page you‚Äôre on and appends the Shopify theme ID parameter to the end, with the ID of the theme you‚Äôre currently previewing added.
To do this, right-click in your bookmarks bar and click Add Page, you can name this whatever you like, I just have it as ‚ÄúPreview Theme‚Äù. Then in the URL field, add the following:
Now click save, and when you click the Preview Theme link while browsing a Shopify store, the URL will be automatically copied to your clipboard:
This will handle any other parameters on there too, so if you‚Äôre browsing a specific variant or have any tracking parameters in your URL, it‚Äôll still work as expected:

This allows you to share the URL of the exact page you‚Äôre working on with the theme ID, and ensures you don‚Äôt run into a scenario where your client has forgotten to click the preview link before taking a look at the page, and wondering where all your incredible work has gone.

[Shopify Editions Winter ‚Äò24](https://www.shopify.com/editions?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-42-making-theme-previews-easy) - registration is now available for the latest drop of Shopify features!

[Updates from Shopify engineering](https://www.shopify.com/news/performance%F0%9F%91%86-complexity%F0%9F%91%87-killer-updates-from-shopify-engineering?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-42-making-theme-previews-easy) - if you‚Äôre interested in the nitty gritty details of what changes are being made to the Shopify admin and backend, this is for you

[Algomo for Shopify](https://www.algomo.com/shopify-ai-agents?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-42-making-theme-previews-easy) - whilst I remain broadly skeptical of AI, I think it has its uses, and this is an interesting upcoming integration from Algomo which will give customers really quick access to different information from your store including their order info and product availability, could be useful!

[Easy Student Discounts](https://apps.shopify.com/student-discounts?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-42-making-theme-previews-easy) - admittedly, I‚Äôm somewhat biased here since Radiant, the app dev, are my most recent employer. However, they do great work with the app side of their agency and ESD is a really well designed, easy to use app for any of your clients who are looking to offer a student discount without partnering with a third-party system and losing a large chunk of the revenue to them.

This week marks my first as a full-time Shopify freelancer! I‚Äôve been working with Storetasker alongside my full time job at a Plus agency (h/t to Radiant who I mentioned a mere paragraph ago) for a couple of years and steadily growing my portfolio as a freelancer, so I think my number one learning for this edit is patience.

I‚Äôve been doing this job (or at least, something very similar) for coming up to ten years, and once you see that the freedom of freelancing is available to you, it‚Äôs very tempting to jump in with both feet. But, I‚Äôd exercise caution, making sure to build a lasting relationship with your employer and freelance clients to set yourself up and making sure you‚Äôre fully ready before committing yourself to being out there on your own.

After all, you‚Äôre not just going to be able to turn on your laptop on a Monday and have work there ready for you, you have to bring that work in yourself, and it‚Äôs worth asking yourself if it‚Äôs worth the added stress and effort. Get everything you can from the experience of being employed, and then only when you feel like you are in a prime position, go for it!
Take the time to save financially, but also save yourself from taking on too much at once to rush your career, and trust me, you‚Äôll feel the benefits in the long run.

"i only speak liquid" #41: Debugging app issues in Shopify themes,Written by Joe (a Storetasker Expert) NEW!!,,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-41-debugging-app-issues-shopify-themes,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Welcome tomy 1st everedition of 'i_only_speak_liquid'. I‚Äôm [Joe](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/joe-callon?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-41-debugging-app-issues-in-shopify-themes), an expert on [Storetasker](https://resources.storetasker.com/become-an-expert?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-41-debugging-app-issues-in-shopify-themes) & a front-end developer. I have worked within Shopify‚Äôs Plus Support team, agencies, and as a freelancer for a good few years. I‚Äôm looking forward to sharing some of my findings with you lovely lot!

Apps are an essential part of the Shopify ecosystem, but they can occasionally throw up unexpected behaviour in your theme, and they‚Äôre often hard to pin down as the culprit for any issues you might be facing, whether it‚Äôs a broken add to cart or just a visual bug you can‚Äôt quite figure out. Disabling each app embed within the theme editor can sometimes bring you joy, but app developers aren‚Äôt always as transparent about their integrations and it can lead you down a confusing path.

This was an issue facing us within Shopify‚Äôs support team daily as merchants implemented apps over the top of complex themes, resulting in knock-on effects that could have a huge impact on the merchant‚Äôs sales and customer trust. Thankfully, the team found a solution for most scenarios (full credit to the Plus Front End team for the snippet of code!).

Essentially this bit of Liquid deconstructs thecontent_for_headertag which contains the app scripts for your store, and removes any URLs you don‚Äôt want based on an index. Starting with 0 as your urls_to_remove variable will log all the app URLs into your console and remove them all from content_for_header, essentially disabling these apps from running. From here, you can narrow it down to the apps you suspect might be causing the problem, until you find the offending URL. You can grab the code [here](https://smalldev.tools/share-bin/zUEM1SXS?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-41-debugging-app-issues-in-shopify-themes), just add it above the tag within your theme.liquid file.

Word of warning:make sure this code isn‚Äôt included in any published themes, editing content_for_header isn‚Äôt supported by Shopify in any way and could have some unintended consequences, this is purely an investigative tool meant for testing themes only.

[SVGOMG](http://svgomg?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-41-debugging-app-issues-in-shopify-themes)-a GUI editor for SVGs which I use almost daily to help clean up SVG code

[Liquid Weekly podcast - Managing Product Data](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xkBfgT_XE1I&utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-41-debugging-app-issues-in-shopify-themes) - I thought this was a great chat which is food for thought on how data such as metafields and metaobjects should be managed to make data as flexible as possible for your clients in the future

[Bulk Product Editor](https://apps.shopify.com/bulk-product-editor?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-41-debugging-app-issues-in-shopify-themes)- piggybacking off the last recommendation, Ablestar apps are really solid and their editor app is a really effective time-saver, it‚Äôs a perfect example of app developers picking up where Shopify are lagging behind in certain areas, data management being a key one

[HouseParty](https://housepartyapp.com/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-41-debugging-app-issues-in-shopify-themes) - It‚Äôs nice to see app developers trying something new rather than rehashing the same old ideas:
This app allows you to add an embedded customer forum to a store, which fosters a sense of community with customers and creates more brand loyalty in a way that feels genuine and useful.

It works using Shopify‚Äôs customer records, so you‚Äôre not introducing another layer of account registration or management, which is ideal to keep things simple. The app itself is very nicely designed and works great from my testing!

Coming from a background of working in agencies, it can be overwhelming to be expected to handle all aspects of a piece of work, from conception to project management to the actual development, but I‚Äôve found the greatest weapon we hold as freelancers is setting clear boundaries with a client. When putting together the quote for a project, make sure your scope is water-tight and it‚Äôs clear, step by step, what you‚Äôll be doing as part of the agreed project and what you‚Äôre expecting from your client. This could be adding a numbered list of the steps you‚Äôll carry out within the quote, being verbose about things at this stage is key to ensuring everyone‚Äôs on the same page.

Providing this information not only helps you should the client begin to scope-creep (it happens to us all), but it also leaves the merchant clear on what to expect from you. This can massively reduce the anxiety that comes with handling a project solo, and if you‚Äôre ever feeling out of your depth, you have something to refer back to that outlines where you need to focus your attention next.

"i only speak liquid" #40: Going Headless: Connecting a external CMS: Contentful,Written by Luke (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-40-going-headless-connecting-external-cms-contentful,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Welcome tomy 4th & finaledition of 'i_only_speak_liquid'. I‚Äôm [Luke](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/luke-walsh?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-40-going-headless-connecting-a-external-cms-contentful), an expert on [Storetasker](https://resources.storetasker.com/become-an-expert?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-40-going-headless-connecting-a-external-cms-contentful) and I love working on headless challenges within Shopify.In January, another fellow Storetasker expert / Shopify dev will be taking the pen for 4 fresh edits üôÇ
I‚Äôve been thinking about what to write for my final newsletter for Storetasker and settled on the final piece of the puzzle - content management systems.

Shopify is getting better at being able to add custom data through metaobjects but it might still not be enough for some users. This is why a lot of headless stores will use an external service to manage their content outside of products and inventory.

One popular service is [Contentful](https://www.contentful.com/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-40-going-headless-connecting-a-external-cms-contentful) which is a paid for service, but I‚Äôve found it one of the nicest to work with. If you are looking for a free alternative have a look at [Strapi](https://strapi.io/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-40-going-headless-connecting-a-external-cms-contentful) which you can self-host.

The first thing we need to do is set up our Contentful client in our Remix space.¬† This is done much like the storefront API for Shopify. We head into our server.ts file and we can put our new code below the init for the Shopify API. This is just a preference as it keeps the external services together.
If we expand our Contentful function we can go into more detail around how it is set up.

First we set up the url that we need to hit. This requires us to set some ENV variables. These will later be set in the Hydrogen channel inside the Shopify admin but for local testing you can put them in your .env file locally.
We‚Äôve set up these two ENVs that we must use for the api to work.
CONTENTFUL_SPACE_ID- the space in contentful you want to use.
CONTENTFUL_ACCESS_TOKEN- the access token that you can generate in the Contentful admin which gives you permission to the instance.

You could also set up something like CONTENTFUL_ENV so that you can target Contentful environments that you can set up in their UI which are useful for testing content or for having separate content tied to a staging site.
If you wish to use this you can update the URL to be https://graphql.contentful.com/content/v1/spaces/${env.CONTENTFUL_SPACE_ID}/environments/env/${env.CONTENTFUL_ENV}

The last thing we need to do before we can use it in our loader is to add the Contentful variable to the Remix context. This is inside the createRequestHandler and inside this is the¬† getLoadContext where we add our new variable. You‚Äôll find this in the same file, server.ts.
Now we‚Äôve done that we can finally use the Contentful API in our loaders.
In our loader we just add the contentful parameter to our context deconstructing and from here we can use it to make a GraphQL call.
Say we have collection data inside Contenful then we can use our new api to call contentful and pass in our GraphQL query along with any variables.

To give you a full example, our query might look like this. It‚Äôs nice to have your queries in their own files exported as const for organisation and code readability, but you can also write them directly in the query parameter if you like. Here‚Äôs an example of it as a const variable in another file.

Note: if we have a content modal called Collection, in Contetnful‚Äôs GraphQL, the collection is also a collection of ‚Äúcollections‚Äù so the schema is collectionCollection. To make it easier, you can install the GraphQL explorer app in your space to test queries etc.
Finally, once we have the data back from the api after awaiting the response we can just return it like usual using Remix‚Äôs json() method like so:

[Contentful GraphQL intro](https://www.contentful.com/developers/docs/references/graphql/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-40-going-headless-connecting-a-external-cms-contentful#/introduction) - the intro into using their api and part of what we do in here.

[Contentful preview mode](https://www.contentful.com/developers/docs/references/graphql/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-40-going-headless-connecting-a-external-cms-contentful#/introduction/previewing-content) - a useful param to now, as preview content is not always returned by the api.

[Strapi](https://strapi.io/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-40-going-headless-connecting-a-external-cms-contentful) - an open source self-hosted option like Contentful if you want more control or a free alternative.

[Boost AI Search & Filter](https://apps.shopify.com/product-filter-search?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-40-going-headless-connecting-a-external-cms-contentful) - if I am not working on a headless site and the Shopify store wants better search functionality then this app is usually my go to.
It‚Äôs easy to set up and has decent customisation options for a developer to be able to tie into it.
Your time as a freelancer is important, so tracking how much you work on something should be important as well.
Whether you bill hourly or per project I still think it is useful to know how much time you‚Äôve spent on something. For this reason, I like to use an app called TopTracker.

You install it on your machine, and it just counts time and you set a note for each ‚Äútimer‚Äù. It is not super complex or has 100 features, but uploads to the cloud, has some reporting and you can break down stuff by client and most important - it is free.

How you use it is up to you but it is great to look back on a month and see how much you‚Äôve accomplished or use it for billing like I do. It can also be a great way of seeing time spent on the most profitable clients or vice-versa.

"i only speak liquid" #39: Going Headless: Moving API calls servside,Written by Luke (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-39-going-headless-moving-api-calls-servside,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Welcome tomy 3rd!!edition of 'i_only_speak_liquid'. I‚Äôm [Luke](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/luke-walsh?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-39-going-headless-moving-api-calls-servside), an expert on [Storetasker](https://resources.storetasker.com/become-an-expert?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-39-going-headless-moving-api-calls-servside) and I love working on headless challenges within Shopify.In 2 weeks, I shall send my final newsie (üò¢) before handing the pen off to another expert. Enjoy!
We‚Äôve looked at some initial choices of headless apps and we‚Äôve also delved into some tips and common gotchas of the Shopify Hydrogen setup when using the documentation.
Now I thought it would be useful to look into how we‚Äôd move a client side api call into the server side.
Let‚Äôs also pretend that we are exposing an API secret too on the client before and how we can do it server side more safely (scary).

In Hydrogen you can use the ‚Äúroutes'' folder to store your api calls. The approach follows the same routing mentioned in the Remix docs for the file or folder naming convention that is converted into a url.
Our example will be creating a folder (you can also just have a file too) that is called:
api.hello-work - this would translate into mystore.com/api/hello-world
Now inside this folder we create our TS file, called route.ts and inside here we can put a special function called action.
It takes three parameters that we can use to get information about the request, params that are attached to the url and the context of our Remix application.
From here we can then inside our action function look to make sure it is a post request and if not we can throw an error back to the client. You can change this to check for any request as needed.
Once we have our data, we can get our hello world api to do something with it and return a new response back to the user. Here‚Äôs a sample of a more complete action and I‚Äôll break it down below.
First, as before we get our params from the action function using object deconstructing and do the same again on the context to get the session, storefront api and env.
Next we check if the request is a POST - then we exit out if it is not. Great to make sure we don‚Äôt let through requests we don‚Äôt want.
If we are a POST request, we continue by grabbing our ENV variable. This could be an API Secret or anything you like.
We then get the json from the request but if it was a formdata POST request, we could do the same but with a different method which I‚Äôve left in the example.
Finally we grab our param from the JSON called bar and this is set up in TypeScript on the data object so we know what to expect.

Once we have what we need, we return the response back to the client with a new data object using the json method which is a nice wrapper function. We pass two params, one called success so we know that we‚Äôve done what we need to and the other called data which in our example just has a string and appends our bar variable.

This is just a basic example, but using this as a base you can do a whole number of things and all server side which is a lot more secure for your application. Of course client side api calls are still perfectly fine to use depending on the scenario.

[Remix Action Explained](https://remix.run/docs/en/main/route/action?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-39-going-headless-moving-api-calls-servside) - the docs from the remix site about the action route

[Remix API Routes](https://remix.run/docs/en/main/guides/api-routes?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-39-going-headless-moving-api-calls-servside) - an overview of how the api routes in remix work in a more general view.

[Remix Routing](https://remix.run/docs/en/main/file-conventions/routes?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-39-going-headless-moving-api-calls-servside#basic-routes) - how you can set up routes based on file structure in your application.

[What I had wished I had known about SPAs](https://stackoverflow.blog/2021/12/28/what-i-wish-i-had-known-about-single-page-applications/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-39-going-headless-moving-api-calls-servside) - a good blog on stackoverflow about SPA applications.

[JudgeMe](https://apps.shopify.com/judgeme?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-39-going-headless-moving-api-calls-servside) - We‚Äôve probably all heard of these as they are a big app on the Shopify marketplace and I do like to advise these for anyone looking for a reviews app.

That‚Äôs not all though, as an app developer I make integrations for a lot of applications and I‚Äôve found JudgeMe to be amazing in the developer/QA process of making integrations for the system. They provide great support, have decent documentation and their QA process is solid. So if you are in the process of adding integrations or want to but not sure where to start, these people are great to work with.
As freelancers we can wear a lot of ‚Äúhats‚Äù from frontend, to backend and devops.
This is more and more becoming apparent as frontend applications like Hydrogen are running more hybrid approaches with a server side and client side stack.

With these lines blurring we may all become more of a ‚Äúfull stack‚Äù engineer so take the time to start to learn some of these ‚Äúbackend‚Äù processes as you might be thrown into them one day even as a FE dev.
"i only speak liquid" #38: Hydrogen tips,Written by Luke (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-38-hydrogen-tips,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Welcome tomy 2nd!!edition of 'i_only_speak_liquid'. I‚Äôm [Luke](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/luke-walsh?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-38-hydrogen-tips), an expert on Storetasker and I love working on headless challenges within Shopify.

In the [previous newsletter](https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-37-choosing-go-headless-hydrogen) I focused on comparing two different headless technologies paired up with two popular frontend frameworks (Hydrogen vs. Nuxt / Nacelle).I‚Äôll be authoring another 2 newsies before handing the pen off to another expert. Enjoy!

Let‚Äôs dive a little further into Shopify‚Äôs Hydrogen and I can give you a handful of tips based on their setup documentation that will help you sidestep some common issues I‚Äôve found working with it in the past.
Tip 1 - Load your product information server side

Use the server side loader to your advantage. Remix is built to make use of node‚Äôs server side rendering, so you can preload your API data on the server and then hydrate the rest of the application.

In Remix, you do this via the loader function, which takes in some loader arguments such as page parameters, the node request object, the application context and more. You can use these to get a product from Shopify like so.
This will run a request to the Shopify Storefront API, cache the response and we send it to the frontend as json in the return that can be used in the main React component how you wish.

Important to note, this method only ever runs on the server. So you don‚Äôt have access to some things you might be used to on the client side like the ‚Äúwindow‚Äù object etc. It‚Äôs a common gotcha when working on server side apps.
My example is close to what is on the Shopify Hydrogen website but with one quite important change. Caching.

You should cache your API requests so that multiple requests don‚Äôt actually hit the shopify server for the response but their cache store for that product.¬† There‚Äôs plenty of options and you can set them via helper methods like in the example which looks like this:
Or by manually passing in an object that accepts a couple of properties such as max age and the revalidation time.
Whatever you decide depends on your use case, but caching is better than not caching for anything that does not change often like product information etc.
Tip 3 - Defer your non critical information

Now you are loading in your information and caching, you want to make sure that you only load the minimal amount of information on the server, otherwise you run the risk of making the user wait for everything to be ready before they see anything.

Remix uses a defer method and Await component so you can do this easily. Say we had some recommended products along with our main product. We change the ‚Äújson‚Äù method into the ‚Äúdefer‚Äù one like so.
Then we update our component to display the product information as soon as we have it, but we don‚Äôt show the recommended products until we get the resolve back from the promise.

The Suspense component allows you to set up a fallback, this is usually a component that shows a loading skeleton etc. Inside it is the Await, this component takes in the promise that we pass from the defer method in our loader and once that resolves, we show the actual component. We pass in the data to the new component from the return of the Await component and it renders as normal.
With this, we load the page quickly with the main product data, then we just show a loading state until Shopify comes back with the recommended products.

Using defer, you can load any non-critical data onto pages but it is not limited to Shopify. Third party apps and other data can also be loaded into the loader and deferred. This reduces the risk of slowing down your site because of slow response times from other parties which you have little control over.
Tip 4 - Only load your information once if you can

In some cases in the past I‚Äôve seen multiple requests to the Shopify API for the same information over and over because the API request is tied to the route params changing or the variant selection buttons.
If you see this, or do it by accident (we‚Äôve all been there) then just think about how you can store the information, reuse it to save network requests and make things quicker.

One example is to use a ‚ÄúState‚Äù store which in React is called a Context. By wrapping your product route in say a Product Context. You can set up a store for product information that is returned from the API.

Then set up your selected options in the context too. That way, rather than asking Shopify to return information based on the selected options from the API, you can just filter the product variant data you have and update the product page.

[Shopify caching](https://shopify.dev/docs/custom-storefronts/hydrogen/data-fetching/cache?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-38-hydrogen-tips) - here‚Äôs the documentation to the Shopify api caching which explains in more detail the methods available.

[Remix performance docs](https://remix.run/docs/en/main/guides/performance?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-38-hydrogen-tips) -¬† This is a WIP doc from remix but it outlines some useful things to consider when you want to improve performance of your Hydrogen storefront.¬† This should also go in pair with the [streaming documentation.](https://remix.run/docs/en/main/guides/streaming?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-38-hydrogen-tips)

[React context](https://react.dev/learn/passing-data-deeply-with-context?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-38-hydrogen-tips#) - here‚Äôs the documentation that explains the context store/state in React which will help get you started.

[Appy Stamp - Loyalty and Rewards](https://apps.shopify.com/appy-stamp-loyalty-rewards?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-38-hydrogen-tips) - Okay so this will be a little (hugely) biased. As the app I like is one of my own. I built this app as an alternative to the many ‚Äúpoints‚Äù based loyalty programs for a lot of my clients who wanted an easier to understand program.
It offers a lot of similar functionality such as various reward types, VIP programs, integrations etc but I also wanted pricing to be fair and no lock away features behind expensive paywalls.

I‚Äôve learned that continuous iteration is better than trying to perfect something before releasing it.¬† We all get stuck in the mindset that something is not done until it works flawlessly, has every function we could ever think of, and is perfect for the end user.

In reality this is never the case, we have time constraints and bugs will always happen no matter how good we are. For this reason, it is more important to continually improve and iterate on your code and coding practices.

The small changes and improvements you make will compound interest down the line which is going to save you time in the future. Don‚Äôt try and make a whole website faster, choose a key area like a PDP and start there and then choose a particular area which might be loading slower and improve that first.

Build up these iterations and eventually the entire site will be faster and hopefully because you did it in stages, you improved, your code got better and you passed on each learning to the next piece of code.
Now you can go back and start on the first component‚Ä¶ good luck!

"i only speak liquid" #37: Choosing to go Headless: Hydrogen or other?,Written by Luke (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-37-choosing-go-headless-hydrogen,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Welcome tomy firstedition of 'i_only_speak_liquid'. I‚Äôm [Luke](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/luke-walsh?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-37-choosing-to-go-headless-hydrogen-or-other), an expert on Storetasker and I love working on headless challenges within Shopify. As always - I‚Äôll be writing 4 editions before handing the pen off to another expert. Enjoy!

Recently, I've been working with more and more clients that are looking to move their Shopify storefront to a ‚Äòheadless‚Äô frontend. If you are new to the term, it is a technique of separating the client side shop from Shopify and running another piece of technology. These are typically popular frontend frameworks React or VueJS.
I hear you ask ‚ÄúBut what one should I choose?‚Äù.
It depends on what you are more proficient in and how much you still want to lean on Shopify.
Hydrogen, is Shopify‚Äôs internal homegrown headless setup that is based on React/Remix and can be integrated nicely into the Shopify admin as an additional Sales Channel.

Vue devs have a bit more setup needed as there‚Äôs no Hydrogen for Vue. This means we‚Äôll focus on a combo of Vue/NuxtJs and a third party company called Nacelle that helps connect the Shopify data into Nuxt.
- It‚Äôs Shopify‚Äôs technology which means it should be the most supported inside their own ecosystem.
- It uses less moving parts than the Vue alternatives which means less to manage, upgrade and maintain.
- Set up and deploying is very easy to manage inside the admin and deployed through Oxygen another Shopify platform.
- It‚Äôs free to use (at the moment).
- It uses Remix as the base set up for SSR (Server side rendering) and can have a steep learning curve for devs if they are used to just Liquid.
- It‚Äôs still fairly new and a little undocumented so you‚Äôll need previous experience in React/Remix to really get it working.
- It might not make sense for smaller businesses as the additional control means a lot more extra dev time (good for us though)
- Vue is seen as a bit easier for devs to learn (if you are using the options API) that breaks up the flow into more obvious chunks.
- Shopify data is indexed externally in Nacelle which means that your store has a bit more redundancy. Also caching is handled by Nacelle which is easier to set up compared to the Storefront API.
- More flexibility on builds and deployment. Not using Hydrogen means you have more control on who hosts your builds and how you build it
Things to consider using Nuxt / Nacelle
- Nacelle is a paid for platform, so there is an additional cost to use the service.
- Additional services mean more to maintain - although Nacelle is managed serviced you will still have to do some bits.
- Like React, Nuxt is for server side rendering and can be a bit of a learning curve to manage the server side and client side pages.

So there you have it, hopefully enough to get you started on your journey with headless apps and Shopify. There‚Äôs no right or wrong answer when it comes to choosing one framework over the other. Just go with the one you feel most comfortable with and paired up with your clients needs for the project.

[Shopify Hydrogen Docs](https://shopify.dev/docs/custom-storefronts/hydrogen/getting-started?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-37-choosing-to-go-headless-hydrogen-or-other): This will show you how to get started using Hydrogen and you can install it on development stores so you can play with it and learn how it works.

[Nuxt Docs](https://nuxt.com/docs/getting-started/introduction?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-37-choosing-to-go-headless-hydrogen-or-other):Nuxt is like remix as we‚Äôve talked about and has a decent set of docs on how to get set up.

[Nacelle Docs](https://docs.nacelle.com/docs/pwa-nuxt?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-37-choosing-to-go-headless-hydrogen-or-other):Nacelle‚Äôs docs again have a decent amount of content to help you get connected and have a section specifically for Nuxt which helps the initial setup greatly.

We‚Äôve all chosen to be a freelancer for different reasons and sometimes I think we all try to be an ‚Äúexpert‚Äù in everything that the web has to offer. It‚Äôs okay to not know everything and to tell clients that you do not know off the top of your head and will let them know about a question they had etc after.

This is also important to know when it comes to new tech like Hydrogen, React and Vue etc. We all started out somewhere and a lot of the time you‚Äôll learn a lot more getting stuck in but the key,super key partis, you have to put in the effort to learn and keep on learning.
I‚Äôve found the greatest improvement in my skills because my hobbies align a lot with what I work on. I love to tinker in linux servers
column2: creating Docker containers and building my own commercial Shopify apps. All these hours spent outside of billable hours help when I come up against a new client and they want something new or different. It feels more familiar to be confident diving into new docs, planning a new strategy and making sure I feel comfortable that I can take on the project with any additional discovery needed.

Welcome to 'i_only_speak_liquid' by Storetasker, where active Shopify developers like me ([Billy](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/billy-noyes?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-36-hiding-products-from-search-results)) share the learnings we face daily. This is my 8th and final edition of ‚Äòi_only_speak_liquid‚Äô. Enjoy!

A common problem clients always raise to me is that they have products on their Shopify stores, that they like to have in place for features such as free gifts or upsells, and they do not want these items to be discoverable or indexed. This is especially the case if the item is free, since users could find this product and be able to purchase it without meeting the requirements.

Thankfully Shopify have thought of a great and simple way for merchants to be able to prevent this issue. It only takes a couple minutes to get setup and uses metafields, so most clients will be very familiar with the process and can easily manage it.

You start by creating a new product Metafield with the Namespace 'seo' and key 'hidden‚Äô. The Metafield type should then be ‚ÄòNumber‚Äô, just like the example in the screenshot below. The client can then set the Metafield of each product that should be hidden to the value ‚Äò1‚Äô.

By adding this Metafield, Shopify will automatically trigger a new robots metatag to be added to the product page which will ensure that bothnoindex‚Äôing andnofollow‚Äôing are in place - This essentially means that search engines will not index the product page and display it within the search results when a potential customer searches for the brand or products.

Whilst adding in custom Liquid code to a template is quite easy for a developer, this is a very helpful and useful feature that Shopify has automatically added, and is definitely something that is requested from me all the time.

[Ayush Soni](https://x.com/ayushsoni_io/status/1715632867059872041?s=20&utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-36-hiding-products-from-search-results): Each week Ayush shares 10 beautiful websites and I‚Äôve used it as an amazing source of inspiration since I found their Twitter account

[Shopify Schema Builder](https://tkdallman.github.io/shopify-schema-builder/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-36-hiding-products-from-search-results): If you‚Äôre ever having a difficult time trying to find the different schema types, this Schema Building tool will definitely help you

[Section Rendering API](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LtogqzYUrPU&ab_channel=SaadSaif&utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-36-hiding-products-from-search-results): Shopify‚Äôs Section Rendering API is one of the easiest ways you can reload a section‚Äôs content without needing to reload the page or implement a lot of Javascript code to implement the dynamic events. This tutorial is a great way of quickly learning how the API works and what is possible.

I‚Äôve recently been using the EG Auto Add to Cart Free Gift app for a project and was really happy with how well it works. It‚Äôs an app that allows you to add items to the customer‚Äôs cart based on specific rules. For example specific scheduling, targeting specific visitors and customers based on tags and different user groups, as well as specific products or collections, and cart values.
It‚Äôs also part of the ‚ÄòBuilt for Shopify‚Äô program which is great to see and assures your clients that the apps being added to their store are verified by Shopify.

"i only speak liquid" #35: Re-orderable Metaobjects,Written by Billy (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-35-reorderable-metaobjects,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Welcome to 'i_only_speak_liquid' by Storetasker, where active Shopify developers like me ([Billy](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/billy-noyes?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-35-re-orderable-metaobjects)) share the learnings we face daily. This is my 7th edition of ‚Äòi_only_speak_liquid‚Äô. Enjoy!
Recently, I have been working on a custom collection page which required the client to be able to create a list of filters, the main label for these filters and also control the order.
Usually this could have been controlled through something like a comma separated list as a theme setting, for example:

Whilst this method definitely meets all of the requirements needed by the client and would allow me to build the filters in Liquid, it is not the most client friendly or very manageable. If the client accidentally forgets to use a comma or does not add the label before the filter, it starts to break the code.

Since Metaobjects have been released by Shopify, I am constantly finding out about the many use cases for them and how powerful they really are. I have since stopped using lists like the comma separated one above and have made the switch to using Metaobjects instead.

One issue that I have had is how you can reorder Metaobject entries and give the client control over the order. I‚Äôve recently been shown a really good way of handling this and definitely think it will be useful for many other developers.

You start by creating a new Metaobject, this will be used for the individual entries, for example this will be for the actual filter itself - for my specific usecase all I needed was the label and the value.

You then create another new Metaobject, which will be used for the list and can be achieved by adding a field with the type Metaobject and choosing ‚ÄòList of entries‚Äô. This will allow you to then add all of your filters to the filter list and the client can reorder them as needed.

One issue I have found with Metaobjects is that sometimes specific types can result in confusing code, it can also be difficult to loop through certain pieces of data and return the code in JSON format.

Below you can see how I was able to loop through the Filter List and create a global variable that I can then use within my Javascript code to access all of the set filter labels and values by the client.

"i only speak liquid" #34: Section Index,Written by Billy (a Storetasker Expert),,,https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-34-section-index,"p span[style*=""font-size""] { line-height: 1.6

Welcome to 'i_only_speak_liquid' by Storetasker, where active Shopify developers like me ([Billy](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/billy-noyes?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-34-section-index)) share the learnings we face daily. This is my 6th edition of ‚Äòi_only_speak_liquid‚Äô. Enjoy!

On the 18th September I saw an update on Shopify‚Äôs developer changelogs that I have been looking forward to for a very long time. As part of a performance update, Shopify have created the newindexproperty which can be used to return the position of a section within it‚Äôs location.

If you are using theimage_tagfilter, lazyloading will now automatically be applied for any section after the first three. This means that you won‚Äôt have to update any of the code and your clients will be benefiting from this update already.
However, if you need more control, Shopify also have you covered. You can now usesection.indexand the 0-based index versionsection.index0to return the position within the location.
This position number can then be used within your code to add conditions which will help benefit performance. For example, if you wanted an image to either be loaded lazily or eagerly.

Another solution that I‚Äôve recently used in a project and really works well with the concept of sections everywhere, is using thesection.indexto determine whether the section heading should be ah1tag or an alternative HTML tag. Previously, I would have to create a section setting that allows the client to choose, but often clients may not be aware of which type of tag they need to actually choose or this can simply get missed.

Shopify have released a full blog post about this update and you read more about it[here](https://performance.shopify.com/blogs/blog/announcing-new-liquid-features-for-better-web-performance?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-34-section-index).

- Shopify Theme File Search:We all hate it when we have to edit code within Shopify‚Äôs built-in code editor, but this is definitely a game changing Chrome Extension that makes the process a lot easier. It injects a search bar into the code editor that allows you to search for specific pieces of code and even Regex

If you read my previous post about[enrichiching your navigation](https://ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com/p/speak-liquid-28-enrich-navigation), you‚Äôll know that I love the Shopify app Mechanic and the features it provides. I recently found another great app made by the same team and it allows you to lock parts of your site unless the customer meets the specific requirements.

For example you can hide a range of different parts of your site, such as products, collections, prices or even variants. These can then be shown for customers based on their tags, location or even specific passcodes.

I have built similar features many times for clients using custom JavaScript but this app is definitely a nice alternative and provides more features out of the box. It also developer friendly with its Liquid and API.
The app also has the newBuilt for Shopifytag so you know that it is built very well and meets Shopify‚Äôs highest quality standards.

One thing I‚Äôve recently been doing to try to manage my time more effectively is time blocking, whilst I know this is a topic that is discussed all across the internet, I was yet to really dedicate myself to it and see if I would benefit from it. Over the short time I have been trying it out, I have definitely seen some benefits.

I‚Äôve been able to create a better balance between focus periods of work and having breaks which give me a chance to refresh. Time blocking has also mean that I can juggle the many clients and projects I do a lot more effectively. Sometimes it can be hard knowing when you need to switch to a different task but having this written down and specific time available has made it a lot easier.[Billy](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/billy-noyes?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-34-section-index) ([linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/billynoyes/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-34-section-index))"

Welcome to 'i_only_speak_liquid' by Storetasker, where active Shopify developers like me ([Billy](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/billy-noyes?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-33-minify-css-with-liquid)) share the learnings we face daily. As developers, we are often taking on projects that have been previously built and require us to implement new functionality. One common issue I hear from most clients is their site is quite slow or scoring low on Google‚Äôs Lighthouse.

Whilst it would be great if we could always have complete control over how a theme has been built, it is not always possible to completely rewrite code and sometimes the budget a client has does not allow for much time to be spent improving and optimising their site.

I wanted to share one cool trick I found quite a while back. It uses Liquid to minify the CSS code, by removing unnecessary characters, comments, extra spaces and newlines. This helps to reduce the file size and improve the time it takes to fetch the stylesheet.
The Liquid code below can be used to wrap the client‚Äôs already existing CSS inside of thecapture. It then strips and replaces parts of the CSS to minify it.

The Liquid code below can be added to the Liquid stylesheet, e.g. theme.scss.liquid. The already existing css should be wrapped inside of thecapture. The CSS will then be formatted to strip and replace specific parts to create the newly minified version.

Credit goes to Tim on the Shopify Community Forum where I originally found this code[https://community.shopify.com/c/technical-q-a/tool-to-minify-css-liquid/m-p/1123337](https://community.shopify.com/c/technical-q-a/tool-to-minify-css-liquid/m-p/1123337?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-33-minify-css-with-liquid)
- Free iconsI‚Äôm always spending time searching for icons for clients and this site definitely helps reduce that time since it has a huge library of free icons

- Shopify Theme ConsoleShopify CLI now has REPL (read-eval-print loop) tool for testing out Liquid, it‚Äôs very cool to see that they have implemented this and I‚Äôm sure many will find it very helpful

- RunJS AppI‚Äôve also recently found RunJS which is a very nice way to play around and test out new ideas in a JavaScript environment. Of course you could just use Node.JS or an online tool like JSFiddle, but they definitely don‚Äôt look as nice

I have used quite a few different apps to power search and collection pages in the past, whether this be restyling the pre-built options or even building them completely from scratch. Recently, I have been using[Algolia](https://apps.shopify.com/algolia-search?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-33-minify-css-with-liquid)to power a new collection page that I am working on and it has definitely been one of the nicest experiences. I‚Äôm currently building a new site with Vue and the Algolia Vue components they provide have made the whole experience very simple. It provides you with pre-built components that you can also override using Vue Slots.
The app might not be for every client because of it‚Äôs cost but I definitely have enjoyed building with Algolia and would love to work on more projects in the future that use it.

Sometimes it can be easy to forget about freelancers that are at the beginning of their career and are having a hard time finding new clients. I get a lot of messages on LinkedIn about this so I wanted to share a couple ways I‚Äôve been able to meet new clients.

- Share your workNobody is going to know what you are capable of if you don‚Äôt show them. Posting your work, or even ideas, on social media is one of the best ways to show potential clients that you have a very good understanding of Shopify and web development. They‚Äôre able to look through your posts

- Offer your help for freeWhilst I definitely think everyone deserves to be paid for the effort and time they put into their work, it can be hard to gain the trust of clients who are wanting to find developers to work on their sites.Many people now have online businesses, even if they have a small side hustle, this can be a very good opportunity to ask if they need help. Sometimes they‚Äôll just need advice on setting up the smallest of features. You can then use this as an opportunity to showcase your skills and impress them. Once you‚Äôve completed the initial task, ask them if they have any other ideas in their roadmap or any goals they want to achieve, then see if you can help them achieve these for a fee.

If you have any other useful tips like these, I‚Äôd love to hear them and my LinkedIn messages are always open so definitely reach out![Billy](https://www.storetasker.com/experts/billy-noyes?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-33-minify-css-with-liquid) ([linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/billynoyes/?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-33-minify-css-with-liquid))"

Shopify theme development is an ever-evolving field, but sometimes, the simplest things can make a significant difference. While we often use JavaScript events and Liquid objects, not all of us dig deep into the toolbox. So today, let's talk about leveraging Shopify's built-in features to improve the Shopify Theme Editor experience, particularly when building custom sections for clients.

The Theme Editor generates specific JavaScript events for both sections and blocks. These events bubble up and can be quite handy. For instance, you've got events likeshopify:sectionorshopify:blockwhich can be useful in many scenarios.

Imagine you want to develop a popup section in a theme, where each popup is a block. If you're letting merchants customize these popups, you'd want to make sure the merchant sees the changes in real-time. That's where theshopify:block:selectevent comes in. You can use it to show the popup as they tweak it. A simple JavaScript snippet can make this happen:
This is just scratching the surface
column2: you can do a lot more to enhance user experience in a clean, effective manner.

column1: Oh, and let's not forget the Liquid objects like request.design_mode and request.visual_preview_mode. These are super helpful for modifying the behavior of JavaScript elements depending on whether you're in the Theme Editor or just previewing your work.

You can find all the events and objects [here](https://shopify.dev/docs/themes/architecture/sections/integrate-sections-with-the-theme-editor?utm_source=ionlyspeakliquid.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=i-only-speak-liquid-32-shopify-theme-editor-tricks-tools#javascript-events).

- Theme file usage now tracked in the file section in admin. Now, files used in themes are now tracked in the files section of admin. This allows you to easily know when (and by which theme) a file is being used in online store.

- AI in the Help Center. Although Sidekick isn‚Äôt available for everyone yet, the revamped Shopify Help Center now has an AI chat feature. In my experience, it's pretty good at clearing up any confusions you might have.

- Change the primary market of your store. Starting October 1st, Shopify will allow merchants to set their primary market in any currency, regardless of their shop currency. Super useful and claimed feature!
